Falters at times: The claim falters at times by stating that the Obama administration provided the entire $3.7 million grant to the Wuhan Institute of Virology, when in fact only a portion of the grant went to the institute.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide specific evidence or sources to back up the statement that the Obama administration provided the grant to the Wuhan Institute of Virology.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption by insinuating that the grant provided by the Obama administration is somehow connected to the origin of the COVID-19 pandemic, without providing any evidence to support this link.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation to the claim, which is that the grant was awarded to the EcoHealth Alliance, a global environmental health nonprofit organization, and not directly to the Wuhan Institute of Virology.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that not all of the $3.7 million grant went to the Wuhan Institute of Virology, as approximately $700,000 of the total was approved under Donald Trump.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the role of the Obama administration by suggesting that they provided the entire $3.7 million grant, when in reality it was awarded over a period of several years and under different administrations.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating bias in the claim.
